metadata.title: Nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube encapsulating cobalt nanoparticles towards efficient oxygen reduction for zinc–air battery

S2095-4956(17)30707-6 10.1016/j.jechem.2017.09.022 Science Press Scheme 1 Schematic illustration of the synthesis process of different Co@NCNT catalysts. Fig sch1 Fig. 1 TEM and HRTEM images of (a, b) Co@NCNT-4, (c, d) Co@NCNT-8 and (e, f) Co@NCNT-12. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Physicochemical characterizations of different Co@NCNT catalysts. (a) XRD patterns; high-resolution XPS spectra of (b) Co 2 p (compared with PFSA/PTFE-Co membrane), (c) C 1 s and (d) N 1 s. Fig 2 Fig. 3 The ORR performances of different catalysts in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. (a) ORR polarization curves of different Co@NCNT catalysts compared with 40 wt% Pt/C. (b) Chronoamperometric curves (normalized to the starting currents) of Co@NCNT-8 and 40 wt% Pt/C. (c) ORR polarization curves of Co@NCNT-8 at various electrode rotation rates. (d) Koutecky–Levich plots for Co@NCNT-8 at different potentials. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Zn–air battery performance and durability. (a) Discharge polarization curves and the corresponding power densities of Zn–air batteries with different Co@NCNT catalysts compared with 40 wt% Pt/C. (b) Chronopotentiometry (V–t) measurement of Zn–air battery with Co@NCNT-8 at a constant current density of 20 mA cm−2 for 100 h. Fig 4 Nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube encapsulating cobalt nanoparticles towards efficient oxygen reduction for zinc–air battery Haihua Wu a b Xiaole Jiang a b Yifan Ye a b Chengcheng Yan a b Songhai Xie c Shu Miao a Guoxiong Wang a d * Xinhe Bao a d * a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, CAS Center for Excellence in Nanoscience, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, CAS Center for Excellence in Nanoscience Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.19(A) Yuquan Road, Shijingshan District, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences No.19(A) Yuquan Road, Shijingshan District Beijing 100049 China c Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Department of Chemistry, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials Department of Chemistry Fudan University Shanghai 200433 China d Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China * Corresponding authors. Nitrogen-doped carbon materials encapsulating 3d transition metals are promising alternatives to replace noble metal Pt catalysts for efficiently catalyzing the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Herein, we use cobalt substituted perfluorosulfonic acid/polytetrafluoroethylene copolymer and dicyandiamide as the pyrolysis precursor to synthesize nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube (NCNT) encapsulating cobalt nanoparticles hybrid material. The carbon layers and specific surface area of NCNT have a critical role to the ORR performance due to the exposed active sites, determined by the mass ratio of the two precursors. The optimum hybrid material exhibits high ORR activity and stability, as well as excellent performance and durability in zinc–air battery. Graphical abstract High-surface-area and few-layered nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube encapsulating Co nanoparticles showed excellent performance and durability in Zn–air battery. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube Perfluorosulfonic Acid/polytetrafluoroethylene copolymer Cobalt substitution Oxygen reduction reaction Zinc–air battery 1 Introduction Zinc–air batteries have attracted extensive attentions due to their high specific energy, environmental friendliness and ample resource of raw material [1–5]. Zinc is the fourth abundant metal in the earth crust. Unlike conventional batteries, zinc–air battery is completely free of toxic metal species such as lead, mercury and cadmium, making it less expensive and pollution–free. Importantly, the active species for the positive branch of zinc–air battery is oxygen directly supplied from the atmosphere, thus tremendously simplifies the battery structure [6]. Up to now, the development of zinc–air battery is mainly hindered by the sluggish kinetics of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in the air electrode [7,8]. To decrease the polarization loss during the ORR process, many efforts have been made to develop effective and durable ORR catalysts including metals, metal oxides, metal–organic complexes and carbon based materials [9–12]. Among various catalysts, the well–designed non–precious transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni et al.) doped within graphene or carbon nanotubes (CNTs), with large surface area, high electronic conductivity and structural tunability, are promising alternatives to substitute for the most active but expensive Pt catalysts [13–15]. Furthermore, the electron configuration and structural properties of the carbon framework can be well adjusted by heteroatoms (such as N, P, S, B, and F) doping, which in turn prospectively enhances their electrocatalytic performance [16–20]. Liang et al. have developed cobalt oxide/CNTs coupled hybrid as efficient ORR catalyst by growing nanocrystals on nitrogen-doped oxidized multiwall CNTs using a two-step method [21]. Recently, Thangasamy et al. have made attempt to anchor Co3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) on CNTs to catalyze the ORR utilizing a supercritical fluid process under rigorous and complicated preparation conditions [22]. Therefore, convenient strategies are highly desired to fabricate CNT-supported metal/metal oxides hybrid materials. In our previous work, nitrogen and fluorine co–doped graphene/CNTs supported FeNi hybrid material was prepared using iron and nickel substituted perfluorosulfonic acid/polytetrafluoroethylene (PFSA/PTFE) copolymer with uniform distribution and conveniently adjustable ratios of metal ions [20]. The optimum hybrid material demonstrated excellent electrocatalytic activity in alkaline medium and high performance in zinc–air battery. Inspired by this, herein we explore to prepare nitrogen-doped CNTs (NCNTs) encapsulating Co NPs using Co-substituted PFSA/PTFE copolymer by a simplified route. High exposure of NC species is beneficial for the ORR activity by decreasing the carbon layers and increasing the specific surface area of NCNTs. The hybrid material shows high activity and stability for ORR, as well as excellent performance and durability in zinc–air battery. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material synthesis The perfluorosulfonic acid/polytetrafluoroethylene copolymer was prepared by soaking the reclaimed Nafion 211 membranes in boiled 15 wt% H2O2 solution and 1 M H2SO4 solution for 1 h, respectively (denoted as PFSA/PTFE-H). The obtained PFSA/PTFE-H was then soaked in 800 mL 0.1 M CoSO4 aqueous solution at room temperature for 24 h followed by washing with deionized water thoroughly to remove the residual CoSO4 on the membrane (denoted as PFSA/PTFE-Co). The PFSA/PTFE-Co was cut into pieces and adequately mixed with dicyandiamide (DCDA) with mass ratios of 1:4, 1:8 and 1:12, respectively. The mixture was heated to 800 °C in a furnace at a rate of 10 °C min−1 and kept at 800 °C for 2 h in Ar atmosphere at a flow rate of 50 mL min−1, and then cooled to room temperature. The obtained hybrid materials were denoted as Co@NCNT-4, Co@NCNT-8, and Co@NCNT-12, respectively, according to the mass ratio of dicyandiamide to PFSA/PTFE-Co. 2.2 Physicochemical characterizations Transition electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) characterizations were performed to investigate the morphology of catalysts using an FEI Tecnai G2 microscope at 120 kV and a JEM-2100 microscope at 200 kV, respectively. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on an Empyrean-100 diffractometer (PANalytical B.V., Netherlands) with Cu Kα radiation source at 40 kV and 40 mA at a scan rate of 11 o/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a Thermo Scientific spectrometer with an Escalab 250 Xi X-ray as excitation source. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were conducted using a Quantachrome QUADRASORB SI system at 77 K. Specific surface areas of the samples were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) equation. Nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) was used to obtain pore size distribution based on equilibrium model of cylinder pore. The bulk contents of cobalt in the catalysts were analyzed with inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, 7300DV, PerkinElmer). 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The ORR electrocatalytic activities of the catalysts were evaluated in a three-electrode cell (AKCELL3, Pine Research Instrumentation) in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at 25 °C. A commercial glassy carbon (GC) electrode (AFE2M050GC, 5 mm in diameter, 0.196 cm2, Pine Research Instrumentation) covered by a catalyst layer, a graphite rod electrode (Wuhan Gaoss Union Co. Ltd.) and a Hg/HgO electrode (Shanghai Yueci Electronic Technology Co. Ltd.) were used as the working electrode, the counter electrode and the reference electrode, respectively. The potential difference between the Hg/HgO reference electrode and reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) is 0.93 V. All potential values in this paper are referred to the RHE. The rotation rate and potential of the working electrode were controlled by a MSR Electrode Rotator (Pine Research Instrumentation) and a CHI660E potentiostat/galvanostat (CH Instruments Ins.). The catalyst ink was prepared by dispersing 6 mg catalyst in a mixture of 2 mL ethanol and 50 µL Nafion solution (5 wt%, Aldrich) with ultrasonic stirring. The catalyst layer with a loading of 372.8 µg cm−2 was obtained by dropping 25 µL of the ink onto a GC disk electrode by a micropipettes and drying at room temperature. The RDE system was used for investigating the ORR activity at a rotation rate of 2500 rpm and a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. The chronoamperometry (i–t) test was performed at 0.805 V for 7200 s at a rotation rate of 1600 rpm. Commercial Pt/C (40 wt%, Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo K. K.) was also measured for comparison. The loading of 40 wt% Pt/C on GC electrode was 74.6 µg cm−2. The electron transfer number (n) was calculated based on the Koutecky–Levich (K–L) equations as follows: 1 j = 1 j L + 1 j K = 1 B ω 1 / 2 + 1 j K B = 0.62 n F C 0 ( D 0 ) 2 / 3 v − 1 / 6 where, j is the measured current density, j K and j L are the kinetic and diffusion-limiting current densities, ω is the angular velocity of the disk, n represents the overall number of electrons transferred in the ORR, F is the Faraday constant (F = 96,485 C mol –1), C 0 is the bulk concentration of O2 (1.2 mol m–3), D 0 is the diffusion coefficient of O2 in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte (1. 87 × 10−9 m2 s–1), and v is the kinematics viscosity for electrolyte (1 × 10−6 m2 s–1). 2.4 Zinc–air battery test The gas diffusion layer (GDL) with a carbon black loading of about 1 mg cm−2 was prepared by coating a carbon black ink containing Vulcan XC-72R carbon black and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) according to a mass ratio of 3:2 onto a Toray carbon paper (Toray TGP-H-060, Toray Industries Inc.). The catalyst and Nafion solution (5 wt%) were ultrasonically suspended in water and then brushed onto the GDL at 70 °C to obtain the air electrode. The loadings of the catalysts and 40 wt% Pt/C were 2.5 mg cm−2 and 0.5 mg cm−2, respectively. Zinc–air battery tests were performed using a home-made device. Zinc plate was used as the anode. The electrolyte applied in the primary zinc–air battery was 6 M KOH. The discharge polarization curve was measured using a CHI660E potentiostat/galvanostat. A 100 h durability test was conducted at 20 mA cm−2. 3 Results and discussion The Co@NCNT catalysts were synthesized via ion exchange followed by pyrolysis under inert atmosphere as shown in Scheme 1 (synthesis procedures are detailed in the experimental section). Fig. 1 shows that Co NPs are encapsulated in CNTs. The particle size distributions are estimated based on 300 particles selected randomly for each catalyst (Fig. S2). The average diameters of Co NPs are 12.2 ± 2.7 nm for Co@NCNT-4, 16.4 ± 3.8 nm for Co@NCNT-8 and 22.2 ± 6.4 nm for Co@NCNT-12, respectively. The content of Co species in the three catalysts decreases with the averaged Co particle size (Table S1), probably due to the deposition of more carbon species on the large-sized Co NPs. HRTEM images in Fig. 1 clearly show the Co NPs enclosed by multilayer graphitic carbon nanoshells according to the lattice spacing of 0.205 nm for metallic Co (111) crystal plane [23] and 0.34 nm for graphitic carbon (002) plane [24], respectively. Co@NCNT-4 and Co@NCNT-8 have an average carbon nanoshell thickness of 8 layers, while Co@NCNT-12 has an average carbon nanoshell thickness of more than 20 layers (Figs. 1 and S3). XRD patterns of different Co@NCNT catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 (a). The characteristic peaks at 2θ values of 44.2°, 51.5° and 75.9° are assigned to (111), (200) and (220) crystallographic planes of metallic Co, respectively (JCPDS 15–0806). The broad peak at 2θ value around 26° originates from (002) planes of graphitic carbon (JCPDS 41–1487) [25]. No diffraction peaks assigned to Co oxide were observed. Sharper diffraction peaks can be observed with increasing the mass ratio of DCDA to PFSA/PTFE-Co, indicating an enlargement in the size of Co NPs and layers of carbon nanoshells, which are consistent with the TEM results. The surveys of XPS spectrum (Fig. S4) further evidence the existence of Co, C, N and O elements in the Co@NCNT catalysts. The Co 2p, C 1s and O 1s high–resolution XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 2(b)–(d). For PFSA/PTFE-Co, the peak of Co 2p 3/2 for Co2+ at 780.5 eV in PFSA/PTFE-Co can be discerned certainly, which shifted to a lower binding energy of 778.6 eV, corresponding to metallic Co in the Co@NCNT catalysts [26]. It should be mentioned that the surface contents of Co in the Co@NCNT catalysts measured by XPS analyses are dramatically lower than the bulk contents obtained by ICP–OES (Table S1), due to that Co NPs are encapsulated in CNTs. Specific XPS study of the C 1s spectra of the Co@NCNT catalysts (Fig. 2c) presents that C atoms in the PFSA/PTFE copolymer mainly converted into sp 2 C = C bonds (284.6 eV) for CNTs construction after carbonization, as well as a small portion of sp 3 C – C (285.7 eV) and C – O (286.7 eV) [25]. Note that the surface contents of carbon in different Co@NCNT catalysts are at a high level ranging between 78.27 wt% and 89.76 wt% (Table S2). The large proportion of sp 2 C = C is expected to improve electronic conductivity and charge transfer during the ORR process [27]. The N 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 2d) are deconvoluted to three peaks centered at 398.5 ± 0.1 eV, 400.9 ± 0.1 eV and 402.6 ± 0.3 eV, corresponding to pyridinic–N, graphitic–N and oxidized–N, respectively, indicative of efficient doping of N atoms into the carbon matrix [28]. In addition, the pyridinic–N and graphitic–N species are dominant (Table S3), which is generally considered active for the ORR [29]. The pore structure of different Co@NCNT catalysts was explored by N2 adsorption–desorption analysis. The type IV isotherms (based on IUPAC classification) with an obvious hysteresis loop (Fig. S5a) illustrates the presence of mesopores. Nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) pore size distribution curves (Fig. S5b) based on equilibrium model of cylinder pore further supports the existence of mesopores with an average pore size of 5.4 ± 0.1 nm. Porous structure of the catalysts may facilitate the mass transfer during the ORR process [30]. Fig. 3 (a) shows linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of different Co@NCNT catalysts compared with commercial 40 wt% Pt/C in O2–saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. Co@NCNT-8 shows the highest ORR activity among the three Co@NCNT catalysts, with an onset potential of 0.94 V (vs. RHE), closely comparable to that of 40 wt% Pt/C catalyst and the same half–wave potential of 0.805 V (vs. RHE) with 40 wt% Pt/C catalyst. In the Co@NCNT catalysts, Co NPs are encapsulated in thick carbon nanoshells, which are unable to contribute to the ORR activity. The nitrogen-doped carbon surface is considered active for the ORR. Co@NCNT-12 with a low specific surface area and nitrogen content shows the poorest ORR activity due to less exposed active sites. The lowest percentage of sp 2 C = C and the highest percentage of C – O on the surface of Co@NCNT-4 probably increase the resistance of electron transfer [24], thus the ORR activity of Co@NCNT-4 is slightly poorer than that of Co@NCNT-8 even that Co@NCNT-4 has the highest surface area and nitrogen content. As shown in Fig. 3(b), Co@NCNT-8 demonstrates a high stability with an activity loss of 17.7% at 0.805 V after 7200 s, while 40 wt% Pt/C catalyst shows an activity loss of 36.9% under the same reaction conditions. To further investigate the ORR kinetics and reaction pathway, we evaluated the electron transfer number (n) derived from Koutecky–Levich (K–L) plots by performing the rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurements under various rotating speeds (Fig. 3c). The fairly linear K–L plots indicate a first–order reaction kinetic related to the concentration of dissolved oxygen in electrolyte (Fig. 3d) [22,31]. The calculated n for Co@NCNT-8 ranges between 3.81 and 3.99 (Table S4), indicative of high selectivity towards four–electron reaction pathway. The practical application of different Co@NCNT catalysts was carried out as the cathode catalyst for Zn–air battery. In Zn–air battery, the cathode is impregnated in 6 M KOH solution and fed with oxygen by the diffusion of ambient air. The porous structure is beneficial for oxygen mass transport across the cathode, therefore, Co@NCNT-4 and Co@NCNT-8 shows obviously higher performance than Co@NCNT-12 (Fig. 4 a). A high percentage of C – O results in a hydrophilic surface of Co@NCNT-4, which is prone to be water-flooded and block oxygen accessible to the catalyst surface. Thus, at high current density, the performance of Zn–air battery with Co@NCNT-4 is inferior to that with Co@NCNT-8 (Fig. 4a). The Zn–air battery with Co@NCNT-8 shows a current density of 188.7 mA cm–2 at 1.0 V and a peak power density of 244.0 mW cm–2, which are superior than those of 40 wt% Pt/C catalyst (Fig. 4a and Table S5). 40 wt% Pt/C catalyst shows a higher ORR activity than Co@NCNT-8 in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution (Fig. 3a). When the KOH concentration is increased from 0.1 M to 6 M, more adsorbed oxygen species blocks the surface of Pt NPs [32], decreasing the ORR activity of 40 wt% Pt/C catalyst in 6 M KOH solution [28]. With increased current density, the performance difference between Co@NCNT-8 and 40 wt% Pt/C is enlarged, due to that the porous structure of Co@NCNT-8 facilitates the oxygen mass transport across the cathode. Co@NCNT-8 also shows a high durability under the reaction conditions of Zn–air battery with a slight decline of 6.9 % (from 1.281 V to 1.192 V) at 20 mA cm–2 after 100 h (Fig. 4b). The structure of NCNT encapsulating Co NPs in Co@NCNT-8 is well maintained after a 100 h durability test as shown in Fig. S6. 4 Conclusions In summary, we developed a convenient route to prepare NCNT encapsulating Co NPs using Co-substituted PFSA/PTFE copolymer. A high surface area and thin-layer CNT are essential to effectively catalyze the ORR benefitted from more exposed active sites. Furthermore, the porous structure of Co@NCNT catalyst facilitated oxygen mass transport across the cathode in Zn–air battery. As a consequence, the optimum Co@NCNT-8 catalyst showed high ORR activity and stability in alkaline medium, as well as excellent performance and durability in Zn–air battery. coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen-doped carbon materials encapsulating 3d transition metals are promising alternatives to replace noble metal Pt catalysts for efficiently catalyzing the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Herein, we use cobalt substituted perfluorosulfonic acid/polytetrafluoroethylene copolymer and dicyandiamide as the pyrolysis precursor to synthesize nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube (NCNT) encapsulating cobalt nanoparticles hybrid material. The carbon layers and specific surface area of NCNT have a critical role to the ORR performance due to the exposed active sites, determined by the mass ratio of the two precursors. The optimum hybrid material exhibits high ORR activity and stability, as well as excellent performance and durability in zinc–air battery.

coredata.dc:title: Nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube encapsulating cobalt nanoparticles towards efficient oxygen reduction for zinc–air battery
